newsitem.title: ALBANIA: Albania says Clinton boosts E.Europe NATO bids.
newsitem.headline: Albania says Clinton boosts E.Europe NATO bids.

text.p: Albanian President Sali Berisha said on Wednesday President Bill Clinton's commitment to NATO's eastward expansion was an important boost to membership efforts by Europe's former communist states.
Albania was the first ex-communist East European country to seek NATO membership and to sign NATO's Partnership for Peace Programme two years ago.

"President Sali Berisha welcomed President Clinton's statement in favour of the admittance of the first ex-communist countries in the North Atlantic alliance by 1999 as a show of important support for these countries' membership efforts," Berisha's office said in a statement.
"The enlargement of the alliance is an extension of security and stability in Europe and the world," he added.
Clinton said in a speech on Tuesday that he wanted NATO to admit new members by 1999, the 50th anniversary of the alliance and 10 years after the fall of the Berlin Wall.
Albania was determined to cooperate with NATO's current 16 member states and fulfill the criteria necessary for membership of the military pact, the president said.
Albania is in the process of modernising its defences and claims it has already met the political criteria for NATO membership.
